@NCAA Thanks, opening a ticket for the team to review.

@dwbit: I realize that the team has discussed this aspect, however, I really think it would be better to use the correct designation here, like:
"Card Verification Value (CVV)" or "CVV (Card Verification Value)".
Also, neither "security", nor "code" is part of the CVV abbreviation mentioned here, so you guys are actually renaming an internationally agreed upon standard designation. I'm not convinced that this approach is a smart one in general.
My advice would be to generally use the internationally agreed upon designations for this security measure (at least for CVV and CVC checksums).

The approved Japanese translation "‰øùÁÆ°Â∫´„ÇíÊ§úÁ¥¢" lacks the meaning of "my" or "individual." In addition, it is ambiguous whether to search *inside* the storage or search *for* the storage. I suggest "Ëá™ÂàÜ„ÅÆ‰øùÁÆ°Â∫´ÂÜÖ„ÇíÊ§úÁ¥¢."

@olavinto (& @dwbit): The way this is worded, the intended meaning should be "Search in/within an organization", not "Search for an organization". Whether you perform the search related to this organization from within or without that organization, is of no consequence.
When no preposition is used, "in" is implied in this construction.

@NCAA and @olavinto . To me, it isn't that obvious. I dug a little into into the web vault and I believe that it could either be one of these 2 types of search. That's often the problem with translating sentences without the complete context. Anyway, there is a place where a search querry is for finding a specific organization.

@olavinto: Well, then it should read "Search for organization(s)" or "Find organization(s)". You "Search for X" when you haven't found the object, you "Search X" when you already have/know that object.
But again, I've seen this exact phrase used for both meanings, so the actual context will be the determining factor in the final output.

@NCAA @olavinto There's one really big problem when translating out of precise context; it's totally impossible not to make mistakes that could potentially mislead users. I like doing it, but I really hope that someday it will be possible to do it in a simulated environment that shows visuals as if it was used as normal. So, in the mid-time or maybe until end of the world, I'm doing my best and let it go as I will do for this one!
@jseb.mercier This is greyed out text that appears in the sidebar after you have tapped on an organization in the sidebar.
@dwbit yeah. Would be great...

This placeholder text changes according to what is currently selected from a vault's sidebar. Actually most search strings appear this way in the UI and there really isn't any special dedicated search buttons or pages. Search is more about filtering in this project and these strings almost always mean "Search (in the currently selected/open list) vault/item type/collection/folder/members...". They should also be kept relatively short so that they fit in the sidebar and the search field. There are a few exceptions and those are formed differently to begin with.
@olavinto: Thx for the update... :-)
@olavinto Thanks for the feedback, we are aiming to reduce the number of projects this year from 4 down to either 2 or 1 and I will look at the possibility of screenshots.

@olavinto Great idea, I'll look into this one.

@Flamare Hi there! üëã Thanks for contributing! I'd rather stick with the inclusive writing since it doesn't hurt to make people more welcome to use the product üòä

Hi @Crocmagnon ! üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüôÇ Thanks! I do not agree with your militant conception of language. I am a woman, feminist, for the inclusion of all, and against this "epicene language" which is a regression. You can read: https://fr.sputniknews.com/france/202102161045232209-vers-une-interdiction-de-lecriture-inclusive-elle-est-en-realite-totalement-excluante/
Even if your militant ideology is only visible on a very small part of the application. it's a matter of principle. Or, I respect your conception, but in this case: Bitwarden must offer two translations, an "French epicene" for radical militants. and a "French" for all those who do not share your militant conception.
Thank you

@Flamare thanks for explaining your point of view!
I‚Äôll think about it and do some more research before taking a decision üëç

@Flamare After doing some research and thinking more about it, I came to the conclusion that we should indeed use the grammatical masculine. * I personally don't have strong convictions on the subject so I'm not ready to fight about it (and I have other topics I need to spend my energy on). * I personally find the epicene writing harder to read, especially for convoluted constructions * It's harder to maintain * At least one other person is ready to fight against (that'd be you üòâ)
And the argument that really clicked with me: It could prevent some users to use the software properly because it would make it harder for them to understand the messages. I'm thinking of visually impaired people who use a screen reader or people affected with dys- troubles like dyslexia.
@Flamare Thanks again for your contribution!
@Flamare I just combed over all the files to search for occurrences of "¬∑" "‚ãÖ" "‚Ä¢" and "(e)", I shouldn't have forgotten any. If you want to double check you're more than welcome :)

Thank you very much for your research and your conclusions @Crocmagnon I think your arguments are very relevant, on people with dyslexia or with screen reading systems, and an difficult and unpronounceable writing.
Thank you for your openness, that you took the time to think about it ! üôèüôÇ
I checked, everything is good !

what does "a key" mean here?

I don't think "suojausavain" is the correct word to use for translating "passkey".
That's what the physical security devices like YubiKeys and Titan Security Keys are called. All the big companies like Google, Microsoft and Apple use that word for them.
Better words for "passkey" would be "avainkoodi", which is what Google calls them, or "todentamisavain", which is the word Microsoft, Apple and others use.

It is not necessary to use plural termination between parentheses. Usually in Romanian, when generalizing, only the plural is used even if there is only one element (Ex. "1 minute", "1 ore"). For maximum correctness, the singular for 1 (1 minut"), the simple plural from 2 to 19 ("12 minute") and the compound plural from 20 to 100 ("99 de minute") should be used, then repeat from 101 (complicated, right?).
Finnish would also like to have spearate plural form.
Plural form please.

trans-unit.source: Setting your KDF iterations, memory, and parallelism too high could result in poor performance when logging into (and unlocking) Bitwarden on slower or older devices. We recommend changing these individually in small increments and then test all of your devices.

Vi rekommenderar att du √§ndrar dessa individuellt i sm√• steg och sedan testar alla dina enheter.

trans-unit.note: Very much doubt that this will make sense in all languages‚Ä¶

@NCAA Yeah, I agree. In Finnish, for example, this requires changing the word order. For this reason I have used only a dot . for this string and moved "instead" to the first part of the sentence. According to the context information that should not be a problem since this part is just a part of a plain text sentence with two possible endings which both use the "instead" part anyway (unless some context info is missing).
Still, breaking down sentences generally makes things difficult (more or less). The reason here is the "new item" link that is between the parts.
@olavinto I created a thread for this general problem 2 weeks ago: https://community.bitwarden.com/t/stop-splitting-longer-sentences-into-multiple-strings/63382
@kennymc-c Cool, than you.

@clausstern Hey Claus, thanks for letting us know, can you add the corrected string and then ping me again once that is done?

@dwbit: What this actually reads is the equivalent of "Enter a list of domain names and separate this list by commas.", which isn't the intended meaning (and also makes no sense).
Instead, this text should read, e.g., "Create a list containing domain names separated by commas. ..." or "Create a list by entering domain names separated by commas. ...".
Also, it's "...Android app...", not (never!) "...android app...":
>> "Create a list by entering domains separated by commas. Only "base" domains are allowed, not subdomains. For example, enter "google.com" instead of "www.google.com". You can also enter "androidapp://package.name" to associate an Android app with other website domains." / "Create a list by entering domains separated by commas. Domains only are allowed, no subdomains (e.g., "google.com", but not "www.google.com"). You can also enter "androidapp://package.name" to associate an Android app with other website domains.".
@NCAA Thanks, reviewing with the team!
As alredy mentioned in another comment, Android should be always wrote with a capital "A".

Yeah, also problamatic for Finnish. These should have different plural forms. Doing things this way simply doesn't work for localization because many languages handle plurals very differently and require more changes than just a single word behind a variable.

trans-unit.note: Unless I'm missing out on something important, then Bitwarden currently has no way to detect if 2FA has been turned on for a website or not. Therefore I personally find it to be a bit too assuming to assume that the report's entries are "inactive" or "without 2FA".

@DandelionSprout I agree and have translated this basically as "2FA status of logins". Since this is a report header and the report comes with bunch of summary text, it really does not matter. Shorter length was also a reason for me to use 2FA instead of the complete written translation which would have been "kaksivaineisen kirjautumisen". Several lines long header wouldn't looked good on the sidebar (formerly) or on the box on the reports page (currently).

trans-unit.note: "Your card will not be charged until the trial has ended and on a recurring basis each $INTERVAL$" should be clarified. I am not sure what was intended to express here.
I updated the source string here. Hopefully it is more clear now. It was a bit confusing in English too.

I think "Testversion" is a poor translation of "trial" in this context. "Testversion" = "test version" works kind of for first sentence (i.e. "7 day test version") but not second sentence: "You will not be charged until trail version ends" would also be confusing in English, e.g. what's the difference between the real and test version. Better to us "test time" or "trial time". Hence I suggest the use of "Probezeit": "Ihr Abo startet mit einer kostenlose Probezeit von 7 Tagen. Ihre Karte wird nicht belastet, bis die Probezeit abgelaufen ist. Die Rechnung kommt wiederkehrend jeden/jedes $INTERVAL$. Sie k√∂nnen jederzeit k√ºndigen."
Thanks Stephan! I think you are correct and adjusted the text accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Your payment method will not be charged during the 7 day free trial.
trans-unit.target: Du kommer inte att debiteras under din 7-dagars gratis provperiod.
trans-unit.note:
You don't "charge a payment method":
>> "Payment is not charged via the selected payment method during the 7-day free trial period.".

@NCAA In theory, you can charge a payment method too. For example, a credit card can be charged without any action from its owner (if they have enabled automatic renewal) and there are even payment methods that are not linked to any individual in any direct way (like cryptocurrencies for example so you have to charge the payment method instead of an entity). You can also charge (or bill) an entity too that will then make the payment. Still, your suggestion is better.

@olavinto: Yup, right you are, however, this explicitly pertains to a payment being charged (or rather not being charged in this case) using the payment method registered by the user in the context of commencing the trial period (an approach used by many companies in many contexts today).
To specify, a "payment method" is not something you charge, you actually charge the associated means of payment, or in other words, the account of your bank, financial institution, etc., from where the funds are transferred upon payment execution.
That's why I suggest amending to "Payment is not charged via the selected payment method...", or you could also say "Payment is not charged to your account...".
"charging a method", regardless of what that method might be, just isn't an option.
@NCAA Thanks for the feedback everyone! Correcting these source strings may take a little time as we look at moving from 4 separate translation projects into 1.

@dwbit: My overall point is that "Payment card" should be the preferred designation instead of "debit/credit card" as this covers both alternatives.
From a communications angle, you could say that only mentioning one of the two types, automatically rules out the use of the one not mentioned. This reservation is non-existent for "Payment card".

trans-unit.note:
For other translators, the full sentence reads:
"If you want to add additional seats without the bundled offer, please contact"
In Hebrew, the translation of "additional seats" places "seats" before "additional". So it is not a good practice to split a sentence like this..

trans-unit.source: seats without the bundled offer, please contact
trans-unit.target: platser utan det samlade erbjudandet, v√§nligen kontakta
trans-unit.note: This ends kind of abruptly... or not? Is there something supposed to be appended at the end of this? Like an e-mail address or something else? It matters for translation.

+1. Indeed, it really does matter. For some reason Bitwarden has started to move towards being less localization friendly than it used to be. Recently there has been several additions during the last year or so where sentences are broken into parts and situations where a using variable for some value (like an email address) would make things much easier, and even more importantly, would allow more fluent and natural translations. Not good, not good at all. :(
In this string it would help a lot if the part that follows "contact" was a variable that we could move to where ever we want in the sentence. Since it is now last, we are forced to find some less fluent ways to present this. Again, not good! It's still far from being the worst or even bad, but not a good direction.

The real text is combined out of these parts:
smStandaloneTrialSeatCountUpdateMessageFragment1 + passwordManager + smStandaloneTrialSeatCountUpdateMessageFragment2 + contactSupportShort
Still, I agree that it should contain variables, not be split like that.

What is "Single Organization"
Is one of Bitwarden Enterprise policy. Enabling the Single Organization policy will restrict non-Owner/non-Admin members of your Organization from being able to join other Organizations, or from creating other Organizations. https://bitwarden.com/help/article/policies/#single-organization
Enterprise Policies: 1. Two-Step Login 2. Master Password 3. Password Generator 4. Single Organization 5. Single Sign-On Authentication https://bitwarden.com/help/article/policies/

trans-unit.source:
Hi,
I am requesting a subscription to Bitwarden Secrets Manager for our team. Your support would mean a great deal!
Bitwarden Secrets Manager is an end-to-end encrypted secrets management solution for securely storing, sharing, and deploying machine credentials like API keys, database passwords, and authentication certificates.
Secrets Manager will help us to:
- Improve security - Streamline operations - Prevent costly secret leaks
To request a free trial for our team, please reach out to Bitwarden.
Thank you for your help!
trans-unit.target:
Hej,
Jag vill prenumerera p√• Bitwarden Secrets Manager f√∂r v√•rt team. Er hj√§lp skulle betyda mycket f√∂r oss!
Bitwarden Secrets Manager √§r en helt krypterad l√∂sning f√∂r hantering av hemlig information som g√∂r det m√∂jligt att s√§kert lagra, dela och distribuera maskinuppgifter som API-nycklar, databasl√∂senord och autentiseringscertifikat.
Secrets Manager hj√§lper oss att:
- f√∂rb√§ttra s√§kerheten - effektivisera verksamheten - f√∂rhindra kostsamma l√§ckor av hemlig information.
F√∂r att beg√§ra en kostnadsfri testversion f√∂r v√•rt team, v√§nligen kontakta Bitwarden.
Tack f√∂r er hj√§lp!

This appears extremely messy!

It's not possible to translate this part of the sentence. The word sequence in Ukrainian is different. To resolve the issue, the original text should be changed to: "Open {something} of your organization to grant access to selected members.". In the current translation, I moved the translation from first part to the second part of the sentence, so the second part is too long and might be truncated.

Please give us the full sentence

trans-unit.source: to grant access to selected members.
trans-unit.target: f√∂r att ge √•tkomst till utvalda medlemmar.
trans-unit.note: Would it be possible to please make this a full sentence with placeholders? It's more difficult to translate like this, not knowing what this will be slapped at the end of.

Also, splitting sentences like this makes it hard or impossible to correctly use the necessary punctuation. For example, in Latvian comma must be used before this part of sentence. If it is added in translation here, as a result the comma will be rendered with a redundant space before it.

trans-unit.note:
@dwbit: Unnecessary switching between singular and plural forms for "members":
>> "When members are removed‚Äîan action that is irreversible‚Äîthey can no longer access organization data. To add the members back to the organization, they must be invited and onboarded again. This process, which cannot be interrupted or cancelled, may take a few seconds to complete.".
Even though plural is used in this suggestion, it's quite evident that this procedure will also apply to singular instances (one user/member). Additionally, if we are to nitpick here, you can also say that the current wording "... To add the member back..." essentially is illogical, since that person, who has just been removed as a "member", is now merely "the person" or "the user", who's about to become a "member" again but isn't one yet. So, a more precise wording would be, e.g.:
"When users are removed as members‚Äîan action that is irreversible‚Äîthey can no longer access organization data. To add the users back to the organization, they must be invited and onboarded again, a process that cannot be interrupted or canceled and may take a few seconds to complete.".
@NCAA Thanks!

Please separate this string into singular and plural forms. Otherwise, the translation may appear cluttered and unprofessional. I did not take the singular case into account due to this consideration.

trans-unit.source: Get claims from user info endpoint
trans-unit.target: H√§mta anspr√•k fr√•n slutpunkt f√∂r anv√§ndarinformation
trans-unit.note: @NCAA This is probably related to OpenID acr claims (as is string "expectedReturnAcrValue" too, I'm pretty sure). See: https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-eap-acr-values-1_0.html#acrValues ("ACR" = "Authentication Context Class Reference").
What "...Scopes..." are those specifically?

@NCAA I think "scopes" refers to: OpenID, profile, email address and phone. Can be more See a video about "An Introduction To OpenID Connect" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6DxRTJN1Ffo&ab_channel=OracleLearning at 5m23s. Hope it helps! Also https://auth0.com/docs/configure/apis/scopes/openid-connect-scopes?
What does this mean? What is a 'claim type'?

@lyubomirv A claim is an individual piece of information such as: - name - family_name - given_name - middle_name - nickname - email - address - phone - gender - birthdate - gender - birthdate - profile - picture - website - zoneinfo - locale - updated_at
Scope(s) Are used to request that specific sets of information are made available as clean values such as: Mandatory - openid Standard - profile - email - address - phone
The client application request initially that claims and scopes to be returned to the ID Token
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6DxRTJN1Ffo&ab_channel=OracleLearning
https://bitwarden.com/help/article/configure-sso-oidc/#oidc-attributes--claims
I'd say that "claim" should not be translated. In this context, technical people used to configure these integrations (SAML, SSO, etc) are used to this english vocabulary.
Is the "User ID" custom, or are the "claim types" custom?

@Crocmagnon I think while claims are individuals pieces of information, those can be personalized, not the user ID. "Define custom claim type keys for user identification (comma-delimited). When defined, custom claim types are searched for before falling back on standard types." https://bitwarden.com/help/configure-sso-oidc/#oidc-attributes--claims
@nicklcanada Thanks üëçüèª
Email claim is a claim that specify the email address as an entity https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.identitymodel.claims.claimtypes.email?view=netframework-4.8#definition
Custom scopes for requesting OpenID claims https://connect2id.com/products/server/docs/config/claims-mapping
A claim is a name value pair that represents what the subject is, not what the subject can do. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/claims

plusAddressedEmail
Username generator option that appends a random sub-address to the username. For example: address+subaddress@email.com

trans-unit.note: "Plus Addressing is a great way to quickly create custom (or disposable) email addresses based off your standard email address, by simply adding a "+" suffix string to an existing email address in Office 365. For example, a plus address for kimakers@contoso.com could be something like kimakers+northwind@contoso.com that she could use to sign up for the newsletter at the Northwind web site. Then when Northwind sends a newsletter to kimakers+northwind@contoso.com it will route directly to kimakers@contoso.com. Kim could create an Inbox rule that then moves messages sent to this + address into the "Northwind" folder. Plus addressing support in Office 365 is a great way to more easily manage your Inbox, and even track mail like marketing and sales campaigns." https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/exchange/support-for-plus-addressing-in-office-365/m-p/1170418

areYouSureYouWantToEnableDeviceVerificationTheVerificationCodeEmailsWillArriveAtX

trans-unit.note: @NCAA Thanks, I've passed the feedback along to the team.
@NCAA Agreed -- In addition, it is possible that $EMAIL$ is an email forwarder, in which case it will never itself receive any emails.

@grb: Right. :-)
There are several good reasons for why "...you will receive...", "...it will arrive" and similar variants should not be used.
Basically, if you cannot guarantee beforehand that some specific event is going to happen/occur, then don't claim that it will.
Always keep Murphy's Law in mind! :-)

trans-unit.note: @Inkoming I think it is required to translate "Secrets Manager" too with : "Gestionnaire de Secrets". Not doing so would go the opposite way as I believe was made in a lot the French translations until now. For example, "Vault" is translated and call "Coffre".

Hey! Secrets Manager is considered as a brand by Bitwarden. So we should use it this way. Moreover it‚Äôs perfectly clear and consistent through all the Bitwarden‚Äôs projects (and localizations). In France, the huge companies like Google or AWS are using this term this way too, so the developers are pretty familiar with it (it‚Äôs a very common term in cyber/tech).
Thanks for your message!
@Inkoming Ok. It's not always easy to know what to do!

trans-unit.source: This user can access Secrets Manager
trans-unit.target: Denna anv√§ndare har √•tkomst till Secrets Manager
trans-unit.note: For better respect of capital letters choice for "Secrets Manager" used as a proper name for an important feature, please review my translation: "Activer l'acc√®s utilisateur au Gestionnaire de Secrets."
@HeartCore The source string has no period at the end

@kennymc-c that's correct, but the general punctuation rule of the German language says that they should be added after each simple or compound sentence. Therefore it should be added to the German translation if it is not part of a larger sentence, button, title, link or checkbox.

@HeartCore But this rule also applies in English grammar. There are a lot of other strings with simple sentences that also don't have punctuation at the end. I am not sure if this is really an issue in the source string, they are added afterwards or it has other reasons.

trans-unit.note: Is it really neccessary to break sentences like this? Why cannot variables be used in such cases? In some languages the word ordering in translated text may be quite different, thus making translation of such broken sentences more complicated. For example, in Latvian the best location for the translation of "from the toolbar" would be at the beginning of the sentence (while it is acceptable to leave it at the end, but that feels a bit awkward). While I can move the translation of "from the toolbar" to the first part leaving only period in this part, it most probably will result in a awkward space before the period.
